awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experience in Utah for Sustainable Materials Engineering (ReUSE)
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site has the goal of training metallurgy and materials science and engineering undergraduates in sustainable engineering. This is accomplished through education in sustainability fundamentals followed by deeply embedded learning experiences alongside faculty mentors in Materials Science & Engineering. Students are exposed to sustainability research in the areas of energy, resources, and water taking advantage of the unique geography in Utah. The participants are selected to maximize diversity with an emphasis on Latino, Pacific Islander, and refugee students since these match the high minority populations present in Salt Lake County. A high fraction of participants are contributing to scholarly products such as manuscripts or conference abstracts and presentations. Independent evaluation is being used to monitor continuously and improve effectiveness of this Site. Best practices, lessons learned, and positive outcomes are shared with the broader engineering education community through publications and presentations at the American Society for Engineering Education. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Each participant spends the summer embedded in a research group working with one of 10 participating faculty mentors. Projects involve the development of alternative materials, techniques, and processing routes to achieve more sustainable engineering outcomes in three key subareas: water, energy, and resources. The energy emphasis is placed on replacing critical, toxic, or expensive elements with more sustainable alternatives in order to enable renewable or low-carbon energy technologies. For water, the emphasis is on providing access to clean water through desalination, water purification, and modeling of potential toxins in water and soil. In terms of resources, the emphasis is made on recycling and reducing landfill mass by developing biodegradable packaging and capturing rare metals via recycling of e-waste. In addition to research activities, the participants are also involved in weekly scientific and career-development seminars. All participants present their scientific findings at a symposium at the end of each summer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experience in Utah for Sustainable Materials Engineering (ReUSE) REU Site at the University of Utah provided undergraduate students from across the country with hands-on research experiences focused on sustainability in materials science and engineering. Over the course of five years, ReUSE hosted 38 undergraduate researchers, many from underrepresented groups in STEM, in 10-week immersive summer research experiences under the guidance of faculty mentors.

Intellectual Merit

ReUSE was built around the principle that the materials we engineer today have long-term consequences for environmental, social, and economic sustainability. Students conducted research across three main sustainability themes: materials for energy, materials for water conservation, and materials for resource efficiency (including recycling and landfill mass reduction). Projects ranged from studying critical metals in batteries and efficient polymer recycling to water purification membranes and biodegradable materials.

Research outcomes from ReUSE have resulted in multiple student-led presentations at national conferences (such as MRS and ACS) and co-authored publications in peer-reviewed journals. Several students have gone on to graduate programs in STEM disciplines, aided by the strong mentoring and research foundation established during the program. Faculty reported that ReUSE students made meaningful contributions to their labs, often initiating new research directions or strengthening ongoing sustainability efforts.

Broader Impacts

ReUSE prioritized inclusivity from its inception. Recruiting efforts included  institutions with large Latino, Pacific Islander, and refugee populations—including minority-serving institutions (MSIs) and rural colleges across the western U.S. More than half of the participants identified as women or as members of underrepresented racial or ethnic groups.

To foster community and professional growth, ReUSE students participated in weekly cohort events, including sustainability seminars, professional development workshops, lab tours, and cross-program social events with other REU sites at the University of Utah. The program also hosted an annual Sustainability Keynote and cohort retreat, providing opportunities for reflection, community-building, and visioning future career paths in sustainable engineering.

ReUSE students consistently reported strong satisfaction with the program. Assessments conducted by an external evaluator showed significant gains in students’ research confidence, communication skills, and understanding of sustainability in engineering.

Conclusion

The ReUSE REU Site succeeded in its dual mission of advancing sustainable materials research and broadening participation in engineering. The program equipped students with technical expertise, a systems-thinking mindset, and a deeper appreciation for how their work as engineers can contribute to solving grand challenges in sustainability. As a result of its impact, ReUSE has built a pipeline of motivated and prepared students who are continuing in research and leadership roles in academia, government, and industry.
